title: Persuasive and Argumentative Structures
description: Grammatical patterns for effective argumentation and persuasion

sections.title: Rhetorical Questions
sections.explanation: Using questions as persuasive devices rather than genuine inquiries.

patterns.example: Who wouldn't want a cleaner environment for their children?
But is growth for its own sake really progress?
How much longer must we wait? How many more warnings do we need? When will we finally act?

sections.title: Concession and Refutation
sections.explanation: Acknowledging opposing views while maintaining your position.

patterns.structure: While it is true that X, Y nonetheless...
patterns.example: While it is true that costs would increase, the long-term benefits nonetheless outweigh the short-term investment.
Admittedly, the evidence is not conclusive; however, the trend is clear.

patterns.structure: Critics may argue X, but this overlooks Y
patterns.example: Critics may argue that the policy is expensive, but this overlooks the greater expense of inaction.

sections.title: Emphatic Structures
sections.explanation: Grammatical devices for adding emphasis to claims.

structures.emphatic: It was the evidence that convinced the jury.

structures.neutral: We cannot accept such a compromise.
structures.emphatic: Such a compromise we cannot accept.
The importance of this cannot be overstated.

structures.neutral: I believe this proposal will succeed.
structures.emphatic: I do believe this proposal will succeed.

sections.title: Logical Connectors for Argumentation
sections.explanation: Linking words that signal argumentative relationships.

categories.example: The policy reduces costs. Moreover, it improves service quality.
The data is unreliable. Consequently, any conclusions drawn from it are suspect.
The theory is elegant. However, it fails to account for several key phenomena.
On balance, the benefits outweigh the risks.

exercises.answer: Doesn't everyone deserve access to healthcare?

exercises.instruction: Add a concession before this claim
exercises.claim: The government should invest more in renewable energy.
exercises.answer: While fossil fuels remain cheaper in the short term, the government should invest more in renewable energy.
